headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Urban Outfitters, Inc. Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce Oona McCullough, Director of
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Urban Outfitters, Inc. Second Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce Oona McCullough, Director of Investor Relations. Ms. McCullough, you may begin.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the URBN second quarter fiscal 2017 conference call. Earlier this afternoon, the company issued a press release outlining the financial and operating results for the 3 and 6 months' period ending July 31, 2016. The following
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the URBN second quarter fiscal 2017 conference call. Earlier this afternoon, the company issued a press release outlining the financial and operating results for the 3 and 6 months' period ending July 31, 2016. The following discussions may include forward-looking statements. Please note that actual results may differ materially from those statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projected results is contained in the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
We will begin today's call with Frank Conforti, our Chief Financial Officer, who will provide financial highlights for the quarter. Trish Donnelly, Chief Executive Officer, Urban Outfitters group, will provide a brief update on the Urban brand; Richard Hayne, our Chief Executive Officer, will then comment on our broader strategic initiative. Following that, we will be pleased to answer your questions. 
We have posted a slide deck with key financial information for the quarter and the year to our corporate website. You can find the link within Investor Relations section under the Presentation tab within the Financial News and Events section. Additionally, the text of today's conference call will be posted to our corporate website at www.urbn.com. 
I will now turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Oona, and good afternoon, everyone. I will begin my commentary discussing our fiscal 2017 record-setting second quarter results versus the prior comparable quarter. Then I will share some of our thoughts concerning our third quarter and the rem
componenttext:
Thank you, Oona, and good afternoon, everyone. I will begin my commentary discussing our fiscal 2017 record-setting second quarter results versus the prior comparable quarter. Then I will share some of our thoughts concerning our third quarter and the remaining -- the remainder of fiscal year 2017. 
Total company or URBN sales for the second quarter increased by 3% to a second quarter record of $891 million. This increase included a 1% Retail segment comp, a 4% increase in Wholesale segment sales and a $12 million increase in non-comp sales, including the opening of 8 net new stores in the quarter and sales from the newly acquired Vetri Family restaurants. 
Within our Retail segment comp, the direct-to-consumer channel continued to outperform stores, posting another double-digit sales gains driven by an increase in sessions and conversion rate, which more than offset the decrease in average order value. Negative comp store sales resulted from decreased transactions and average unit selling price, while units per transaction were flat. 
By brand, our Retail segment comp rate increased by 5% at Urban Outfitters, with flat at Free People and the Anthropologie Group. Our URBN Retail segment comp was the strongest in July followed by June, with May being the weakest. 
Free People Wholesale segment sales delivered another solid quarter as sales rose 4% to $75 million. These results were driven by increased space at select department store doors to support our category expansion like FP Movement and growth in our European accounts. 
Now moving on to gross profit. Total URBN gross profit for the quarter increased 8% to $343 million. Gross profit rate improved by 179 basis points to 38.5%. The improvement in gross profit rate was primarily driven by improvement in the Urban Outfitters and Anthropologie Group brand maintained margins with both brands delivering higher initial markups and lower merchandise markdowns versus the previous year. Partially offsetting these improvements was a lower gross profit rate at the Free People Brad primarily driven by lower maintained margins due to higher markdowns to clear slow-moving product. 
Total SG&A expenses for the quarter were up 5% to $224 million. Total SG&A as a percentage of sales deleveraged by 48 basis points to 25.2%. This SG&A deleverage was primarily due to an increase in direct marketing and technology-related expenses to support our strong direct-to-consumer growth. Direct store controllable expenses also increased in the quarter in order to support our square footage growth of 4% in the quarter. 
Operating income for the quarter increased by 14% to $118 [ph] million with operating profit margin improving by 131 basis points to 13.3%. Our tax rate for the quarter was 35.5% compared to 35.2% in the prior year. Net income in the quarter was $77 million or $0.66 per diluted share, a new second quarter EPS record. 
Turning to the balance sheet. Inventory decreased by 4% to $367 [ph] million. The reduction in inventory is due to a 4% reduction in Retail segment comp inventory at cost. The reduction of inventory is not necessarily predictive of future sales growth as we are currently doing a nice job of lowering our recent supply and getting faster turns out of our inventory, as a shown over previous quarters where our sales comp had outpaced our comp inventory growth. We ended the quarter with $328 million in cash and marketable securities. During the second quarter, we paid down $25 million of our outstanding revolver, leaving $50 million currently outstanding. 
As we enter the third quarter of fiscal year 2017, it may be helpful for you to consider the following. We are planning to open a total of approximately 23 net new stores for the year, excluding our food and beverage division. For the third quarter, we are planning 6 new Anthropologie stores, including 1 new Anthropologie store in Europe; 2 new Urban Outfitters stores and 3 new Free People stores. For the year, we are planning on opening 3 net new Urban Outfitters stores, including 1 in Europe; 7 net new Anthropologie stores, including 2 in Europe; and 13 net new Free People stores. For the full year fiscal 2017, we are also planning on opening 2 new Vetri pizzerias and 1 café adjacent to an Anthropologie large-format store. 
Now on the gross margin. We believe our third quarter gross margin rate could improve versus the prior year with that improvement in rate being slightly lower than the 142 basis points we achieved in the first half of the year. Our third quarter gross margin improvement could be largely driven by higher maintained margins at the Anthropologie Group and Urban Outfitters brand, which could be partially offset by declining gross profit rate at the Free People brand. Based on our current plan, we believe SG&A could grow at a low double-digit rate for the third quarter. Please note that we recorded lower incentive-based and share-based compensation in the third quarter of the prior year, which is contributing to the increase in our SG&A growth rate for the third quarter of this year. For the year, we believe SG&A could grow at a high single-digit rate. We believe the growth will be driven by increased investment in marketing and technology expenses, hopefully helping to continue driving our double-digit during the consumer channel sales gains. Store-related expenses are also expected to increase in order to support our square footage growth, which is planned at approximately 5% for fiscal year 2017 capital expenditures for fiscal 2017 are planned at approximately $170 [ph] million. Total spend for fiscal 2017 is primarily driven by new, relocated and expanded stores and the completion of our new East Coast fulfillment center.  
Finally, we are still planning our fiscal year 2017 annual effective tax rate to be approximately 37% for the year and believe our fourth quarter tax rate will be lower than the annual planned rate. As a reminder, the foregoing does not constitute a forecast, but is simply a reflection of our current views. The company disclaims any obligation to update forward-looking statements. 
Now it is my pleasure to pass the call over to Trish Donnelly, global CEO of the Urban Outfitters brand.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Frank, and good afternoon, everyone. The Urban Outfitters global brand had a very exciting second quarter. We delivered record sales volume and drove a 5% Retail segment comp on top of the 4% comp increase from the previous year. Both the North
componenttext:
Thank you, Frank, and good afternoon, everyone. The Urban Outfitters global brand had a very exciting second quarter. We delivered record sales volume and drove a 5% Retail segment comp on top of the 4% comp increase from the previous year. Both the North American and European businesses contributed to the success, with Europe delivering solid comps despite the political backdrop in the U.K. Strong sales partnered with improvements in merchandise margins and the team's focus on expense management allowed us to deliver significant improvement in overall operating margin. 
During the quarter, the Urban Outfitters brand was able to achieve near record merchandise margins through tight inventory management and IMU focus, not to mention compelling trend right products, creative and easy to shop the visual presentations and stores and exceptional imagery with an easy to navigate user experience in our direct-to-consumer channel. The brand's strong partnership with our internal production team led by Chief Sourcing Officer Barbara Rozsas resulted in higher initial margins compared to prior years. Our attention to driving in developing a meaningful regular price business helped improve the global margin significantly. 
Now let me discuss in further detail the various initiatives contributing to the strong top line growth. The record volume in the quarter was driven by increases in regular price businesses across categories, geographies and channels. One of our because shifts in strategy across all merchandise categories has been our focus on exclusive products and offering our customer products he or she can get anywhere but Urban Outfitters. In addition to our own brand product, which as 100% proprietary and a majority of the total assortment, we worked with key brand partners such as Adidas, Wrangler and Fila on special makeups, exclusive styles and UO collaboration. The ability to work creatively and collaboratively with brands we admire who get Urban Outfitters and get our customer has been really rewarding and the response to our customers has been tremendous. We saw impressive growth in our own imported women's apparel and accessories businesses across a variety of categories. At the end of the quarter, over 90% of our women's apparel assortment was available only at Urban Outfitters. Today, more than ever, product differentiation is critical, not just as a traffic driver to both direct-to-consumer and stores, but more importantly, is an obligation we have to our core customer. Our customer looks to us for unique products and first to trend and exclusive product offering ensure her she won't be wearing something offered anywhere 
else. Globally, the brand also saw impressive growth in what we previously referred to as emerging categories, specifically intimates, home and beauty. Within intimates, we've had great response to our broad and undies program as well as our exclusive buys and colors in Calvin Klein. We're also seeing really nice traction in our lounge and dorm offering,  and we will continue to build upon this success as we've seen. 
In addition to intimates, we're seeing sizable growth and outside in our home division. This is an important category in the lives of our 18 to 28 year old customer, whether they're moving into their dorm room or their first apartment. The small space and on-campus home marketing campaigns and social posts were some of our most engaged in the quarter, averaging 6-figure customer likes on Instagram. Also during the quarter, we launched a home showroom in space 15 20 in Los Angeles, one of our large format stores. The showroom shopping experience is truly omnichannel and we'll continue to refine and support this initiative. 
With the majority of our direct-to-consumer traffic coming through mobile devices, the direct and retail experiences need to be seamless and URBN is committed to supporting this with the necessary team and resources. 
Our third emerging category, beauty, continue to see compounded comp growth and increase in penetration in the total business. Here, too, we recognize the importance of exclusivity and first to market and the beauty team has done a tremendous job curating our brand assortment with partners and brands around the world. The unique and different, even in beauty, resonates with our customers and will continue to build out the special offering. 
This brings us to a new emerging category, music, which has always in part of Urban Outfitters' DNA and product mix. Today, we continue to offering vinyl, turntables, cassettes and cassette players as well as wireless speakers and headphones with collaborators like Bang and Olufsen. 
In addition to the product side, and the music category, we're also committed to delivering the experience. Digitally, we've been building out our music video series, UO Live. With tens of thousands of subscribers and views, it gives us another platform on which to connect with our customer while supporting our favorite artists and bands. Our Urban Outfitters music Instagram is growing quickly with mixtape previews and vinyl giveaways, our most engaged customer interaction. 
And finally, our men's business. Although still not where we wanted to be, the progress around the regular priced business, particularly in a direct-to-consumer channel, is seeing great traction. We see a path to positive growth for the back half of the year, with strong and relevant product assortment, including own brand, branded, collaborations and exclusives, relevant and creative marketing strategies and easier to shop in-store visual merchandising set up. We've said from the beginning that the men's comp will follow women's, which is how it's actualizing. The leadership in men's design in merchandising, planning, story visuals and brand marketing has been laser-focused on our customer, on the assortment and on compelling pricing through very excited where the business is headed. 
In addition to our product and experience initiatives, we are in the process of globalizing our team. This change allows us to communicate be seamless global message and a consistent retail and direct-to-consumer experience while leveraging talent and creative assets across the globe. We are committed to pursuing long-term international growth, and this past quarter, we opened a new Urban Outfitters store in Netherlands, bringing our total store count in Europe and the U.K. to 44. In addition, we opened and Urban Outfitters concession within the Selfridge's flagship on Austin Street late in the quarter and are looking forward to seeing success year. 
On a global basis, I'm proud to say our brand saw improvements across all channels and all customer groups this quarter with new, retained and reactivated customer account increasing year-over-year. Another area where we've seen tremendous customer growth and audience engagement is in social media. Our Instagram followers exceeded the 5 million mark during the quarter, increasing 65% over the prior year, and we're now capturing over 200,000 new followers a month. In addition to our national Instagram account, our stores manage our local accounts, which accrued almost 7,000 followers and over 19 million makes in the quarter. Snapchat is important in our consumers' lives, and we're also seen fast growth year with viewership increasing 25% month over month. Urban Outfitters has called out in L2 July Digital IQ index for specialty retail as, "the most prolific ground on the Snapchat platform, posting 6 times the index average with 83% featuring video content." This channel has given us yet another relevant way to connect with our customers and engage in 2-way conversation. A great example of this occurred during LGBTQ Pride Month in June, where our Snapchat stories garnered close to 130,000 views. 
In the 24 months I've been with Urban Outfitters, I'm proud to say we have made great progress. And although there is still a lot accomplished, there have been a number of positives. The results of this past quarter could not have occurred without the exceptional leadership of the Urban Outfitters executive team, and I would like to thank each team member for their hard work, dedication and passion for the brand. Their focus on our customer and the collaborative culture the created for their teens and colleagues have allowed the quarter successes to materialize. And finally, a very special thank you to Meg, whose partnership is invaluable. Her love of Urban Outfitters and for our customers inspires the teams daily and her contributions to this quarter's success were critical. Thank you. 
I will now pass the call to Dick.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Trish, and good afternoon, everyone. URBN produced a record sales and earnings per share in the second quarter with comparable demand accelerating sequentially. May is typically our biggest month for the quarter, but as we suggested on our May con
componenttext:
Thanks, Trish, and good afternoon, everyone. URBN produced a record sales and earnings per share in the second quarter with comparable demand accelerating sequentially. May is typically our biggest month for the quarter, but as we suggested on our May conference call, unseasonably cold weather in the eastern half of North America depressed and delayed apparel purchases. As a result, total Retail segment comparable sales in May were negative. Fortunately, the weather shifted in June and sales rebounded strongly. July sales jumped even higher, generating the best comps of the quarter. 
Given the weak start to Q2, we're very pleased our final sales number show a positive Retail segment comp, and we're delighted to report record second quarter earnings per share. The monthly sales curve was similar across all brands, but overall the results of very. 
So let me say a few words about each brand's performance. First, the Urban brand. As Trish just recorded, Urban produced a terrific quarter. All major product categories posted positive comp sales except men's, and a number of categories delivered double-digit comps. Urban's European business also experienced strong comp games with seemingly little impact on the business from the Brexit vote. Not only did the total Urban brand produced its best comps in 12 quarters, it also continue to deliver strong regular price sales; managed its leanest quarterly markdown rate as far back as brand records go; improved initial margins; administrate high inventory and expense controls; and created a flurry of outstanding marketing events and campaigns. All of these factors combined to create record second quarter sales and one of the most profitable second quarters in the brand's history. 
Brand momentum at the end of Q2 was powerful. Therefore, the team believes they will continue to please and excite customers with new fashion and new marketing campaigns in the second half. My congratulations go to Trish, Meg and the entire Urban Outfitters team on both sides of the Atlantic for planning and delivering an exceptional quarter.  I'm so proud of what the team has accomplished over the past 2 years. Urban has now regained its position as a fashion leader for young adults, and I couldn't be more excited for the brand's future. 
Turning your attention to Free People. In Q2, the brand posted flat Retail segment comps and a mid-single-digit increase in wholesale sales. The brand opened 5 new stores during the quarter and achieved total Retail segment revenue growth of 8%. Almost all product categories in the Retail segment delivered positive comp sales in the quarter with most of the gains driven by higher promotional activity. As we discussed on last quarter's call, Free People entered the second quarter with excess Retail segment inventory. The press aggressively cleared their stock during the quarter by taking additional markdowns, which lifted sales, but depressed margins. I'm pleased to report that comparable retail segment inventory at quarter's end fell by 8% on a year-over-year basis. Inventory is now more current and weeks of supply more in line with sales. As such, we believe the brand is positioned to deliver lower markdown rates in the second half than those experienced in Q2. Although the brand team has made significant progress in terms of inventory management, their goal is to further reduce the average weeks of supply. Looking forward, the brand is encouraged by some excellent early fall sign of its newest fashion offering, especially in this direct channel. Regular price sales in that channel are running nicely positive, but haven't been strong enough to overcome lower markdown sales and negative store sales, so total Retail segment sales are negative. The brand will continue to make adjustments to their assortments based on these early reads, but the team believes the Retail segment results, which are up against multiyear positive comparisons, could remain difficult in the back half. Meanwhile, the Free People Wholesale team continue to produce excellent quarterly results in spite of a difficult environment. The headwinds to growth in this channel have been well documented. Still, the team delivered a 4% increase in year-over-year sales in the quarter and 9% growth for the first half. This growth was driven by continued success and expanded categories such as FP Movement and significant growth in European businesses where quarterly sales almost doubled versus the same period last year. 
The team believes there is significant wholesale growth opportunity remaining in Europe. Looking ahead, timing issues where the wholesale shipments in the third and fourth quarters last year create easier comparisons for Q3 while Q4 is more difficult. In spite of this, falling holiday bookings are strong and the team believes they can return to double-digit growth for the back half of the year. I thank Meg, Sheila, Dave and Chrissy and the entire Free People team. Although not their finest results, the quarter marked a return to fundamental discipline that will benefit the brand going forward. Given the enormous creativity housed within the brand, I'm confident that the Free People will continue to delight its customers with fresh fashion and inspiring environment. I'll take this opportunity also to recognize and congratulate Sheila Harrington on her recent promotion to the role of the brand President, reporting to Meg. Sheila has been instrumental in growing the brand over her 13-year tenure at Free People, excluding extremely successful launches of all the Free People product extensions from intimates to Movement. Sheila, thank you for your many contributions and congratulations to you. 
Next, I'll speak to the Anthropologie brand. Although the brand reported a negative 2.5% comp for the quarter, there were numerous bright spots to report. Anthropologie Europe delivered positive comp sales. Again, we saw no change in customer's demand from the Brexit vote. Almost all Anthropologie product categories performed well in the quarter with 6 of 7 generating double-digit positive comps. Only women's apparel was negative. Due to exceptional inventory management, the brand was able to limit markdowns in the apparel category and decreased the total markdown rate on a year-over-year basis by more than 100 basis points. This decrease in markdowns in combination with very strong IMU improvement drove significant year-over-year increases in merchandise margins on both a rate and dollar basis. The result, in spite of negative overall comps, Anthropologie generated more operating profits in Q2 of this year than in the same period last year. 
Obviously, the team's focus is on turning the women's apparel business around, and I believe the brand is making slow but steady progress. Reaction to Anthropologie's apparel assortment on a comp basis improve sequentially in the quarter. Areas of strength include dresses, which registered strong double-digit comp gains and woven tops, which improves the season progress. The brand believes the apparel assortment will continue to evolve throughout the fall holiday season and feels positive about their assortments in a growing number of apparel classifications. Certainly, reenergizing this category is the brand's #1 immediate goal. 
Strong performance of the expanded categories such as home, beauty, BHLDN and Terrain continues to be a brand highlight. All expanded categories ahead of plan and are fueling the increases in the direct-to-consumer business and the stellar performance of the 2 new larger-format stores. Home is the most developed of these categories and continues to surprise on the upside. We're excited to see customer reaction to the September Home Journal, which will drop in mid-September and have 42% more pages than last year's book. The brand's beauty assortment is also connecting with the customer and show significant sales growth in both stores and online. By the holiday season, more than 130 Anthropologie stores will have a beauty shop-in-shop, up from 70 the prior year. The 2 younger brands, BHLDN and Terrain, which became part of the Anthropologie Group over the last 2 [ph] years, have benefited greatly from the ability to cross merchandise and leverage the Anthropologie Group's resources. Both have experienced significant revenue growth and positive comp sales. BHLDN has the potential to top $50 [ph] million in revenue this year and is quickly becoming our customers go-to destination for her special occasions. The long-term strategic importance of positive customer reaction to these product expansions and extensions, both in-store and online, can't be overstated. Nowhere is that reaction more clear than sales generated at the 2 newly expanded stores in Portland and Newport Beach. Last quarter, we reported on the phenomenal openings each of these larger-format stores had. Now 3 months later, both stores continue to exceed their sales plan and, importantly, for the quarter, both stores averaged higher sales per square foot than the average Anthropologie store. I think that's extraordinary. While 1 quarter's results do not confirm a trend, should this metric continue, the long-term implications for the brand would be found. Furthermore, the team believes there are many ways to enhance the assortment and experience of the stores and build sales even further. During the third quarter, Anthropologie plans to open 2 additional expanded stores, Walnut Creek and King of Prussia. The Palo Alto relocation and expansion is planned to open in the fourth quarter. My thanks go to David, Meg and the Anthropologie team for delivering an exceptionally profitable quarter, and I congratulate David and the team for successfully developing the Anthropologie expanded categories and larger-format stores. 
Before closing, I will briefly comment on trends in the market and summarize our accomplishments this quarter. Over the past several years, the complaint of lack of fashion has become common in the marketplace. I spoke to this subject on our conference call in March of this year. I actually said, I'm not predicting exactly when a change in fashion will occur, but that I saw more fashion excitement in spring than I've seen in quite a few years. I repeat those comments again as we move into fall, except I believe the change is now upon us and our customers are adapting to new looks and silhouettes as we speak. As in all such cycles, some customers and brands adopt newness faster than others, but the fact is there is currently an abundance of exciting fashion happening and this is very good for our brands, for URBN and for our industry as a whole. 
Now to summarize URBN's accomplishments in the second quarter. During the quarter, we generated record sales with a 1% increase in Retail segment comp sales and a 4% gain in wholesale sales and achieved these record sales with 4% Retail segment comp inventory decrease. We also drove strong record consumer sales in part by increasing our marketing expense, grew our year-over-year initial merchandise margins by almost 100 basis points, managed the markdowns of the lowest rate for any quarter in company history, delivered the highest maintained merchandise margin in recent history and earned $77 million in the quarter for a record $0.66 per share.
Finally, in closing, I thank our brand and shared service leaders and our 24,000 Associates worldwide for their inspiring dedication, drive and creativity. I also recognize and thank our many partners around the world. And finally, I thank our shareholders for their continued support. That concludes my prepared remarks. I now turn the call over to your questions.

componenttext: Particularly impressed by the level of acceleration, Dick. headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Kimberly. Thanks very much. I think I don't want to have the group take the entire credit for it is. As I state in my opening comment, there was a weather factor. And I think there was depressed demand in May and we saw a lot of that demand come bac
componenttext: Okay, Kimberly. Thanks very much. I think I don't want to have the group take the entire credit for it is. As I state in my opening comment, there was a weather factor. And I think there was depressed demand in May and we saw a lot of that demand come back in both June and July, but we did see sequential progress in demand over those 3 months. And I attribute that to much better planning on the Urban front this year than last year, a stronger product assortments in every major classification. And I think, Trish was a little reticent to talk about men's, but we're even seeing it in men's now in Urban. So I feel very strongly about Urban. As you know, we still have work to do, as I mentioned in the Anthropologie brand and in some of the apparel classifications, but we saw a nice sequential growth improvements there as well. And definitely, in the home categories and the intimate categories and basically all the other categories performed very well. And then Free People, as I said in my prepared remarks, we've gotten some very nice reads online in the new apparel offering. Some of the other businesses are softer than we want and we're making adjustments in those categories. So I think that we got a lot of momentum going into Q3, particularly in the Urban business. It's pretty strong, and congratulations to Trish and Meg and her team for really engineering that.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I made my comments on purpose that some brands and some customers adopt a different rate. I think, it was particularly the fashion changes, particularly kind Urban, but I think that the other brands have lots of fashion as well and there may be a litt
componenttext: No. I made my comments on purpose that some brands and some customers adopt a different rate. I think, it was particularly the fashion changes, particularly kind Urban, but I think that the other brands have lots of fashion as well and there may be a little slower and adopting it. I think that they will adopt it. I mean, this is fashion change that's happening, and my experience is once it starts to happen, there's not much that stops it. I do think that Free People has a lot of fashionable items in there apparel area and, as I said, it's only a couple of the other categories that are softer. So I think that those Free People and Urban are in the sweet spot with fashion. Anthro is going to get there. I'm quite confident of it. It just might take an extra couple of points.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Paul Lejuez from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question is from Paul Lejuez from Citigroup.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dick, can you -- you've talked about the traffic challenges out there for some time, just a general pressure in the retail landscape. The new fashion that you're talking about, do you think that's enough to offset the traffic pressures for you guys? And I
componenttext: Dick, can you -- you've talked about the traffic challenges out there for some time, just a general pressure in the retail landscape. The new fashion that you're talking about, do you think that's enough to offset the traffic pressures for you guys? And I'm curious if you think the same about the industry as a whole and how that ties into what you expect for the second half of the year?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, things for the question. I think that Urban is definitely benefiting from a lot of the initiatives they're doing, not just for the good fashion, but the social media work that they're doing and the marketing work they're doing. In July, they ac
componenttext: Yes, Paul, things for the question. I think that Urban is definitely benefiting from a lot of the initiatives they're doing, not just for the good fashion, but the social media work that they're doing and the marketing work they're doing. In July, they actually saw a positive comp store sales in North America and in Europe. They had positive comp store sales, so yes, I think you can make the difference. I do believe that we shouldn't get too negative on stores. I think that there's no question, there are too many stores in North America and we start to see some of those stores going away. Some of our competitors are closing stores that are reasonable rate and, of course, there was just Macy's announcement of closing of stores. So I think, you will continue to see a lot of stores close and go away, and I think, that's a positive thing for the industry and a positive thing for all the people, including the ones that are closing the stores. But I don't think it's a problem with stores per se. I think the store concept is still valid. What I see happening over time is just fewer stores, but probably the stores' larger and delivering more of a unique experience, which could complement their direct-to-consumer business. And I think that, that will be the winning combination. Also, if you don't mind, we're taking a second to talk about proprietary product, which was a question you asked last quarter and gave me a lot of reason to think about it. Like Trish said, this proprietary product, I think, is going to be one of the main drivers of differentiation in the marketplace going forward. As Trish said, almost 90% of the women's product was proprietary in the quarter, in Q2 with a Free People Wholesale and Free People retail, it's 100% and somewhere around 90%. And at Anthropologie, the women's apparel is somewhere around 80% proprietary. Our goal is to really have this proprietary product across all categories, not just in apparel. Currently, apparel is the highest penetration of proprietary products, but other categories like accessories and intimates, which are much less, are trending up. And we believe that over time, they will maybe not exceed apparel, but approach apparel. So our goal is to offer these experiences in stores that it's impossible for customers to get any other place than one of our brands.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Janet Kloppenburg from JJK Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Janet Kloppenburg from JJK Research.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just in Anthropologie. I think you said it, that the approach is accelerating. Are you optimistic that this can improve in the third quarter? And just tied to that, had the inventory levels at Anthropologie balanced and where they should be after the [ind
componenttext: Just in Anthropologie. I think you said it, that the approach is accelerating. Are you optimistic that this can improve in the third quarter? And just tied to that, had the inventory levels at Anthropologie balanced and where they should be after the [indiscernible] in the first [ph] quarter?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Janet, I'm going to let David answer that question.
componenttext: Yes, Janet, I'm going to let David answer that question.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's true throughout the quarter, there are opportunities for us to have different inventory levels that they may have impacted some of our apparel demand. But mostly, the inventory level opportunity was in how we distorted the product and the opport
componenttext: Yes, it's true throughout the quarter, there are opportunities for us to have different inventory levels that they may have impacted some of our apparel demand. But mostly, the inventory level opportunity was in how we distorted the product and the opportunities in learning and where the customers are moving more forward. As Dick alluded to earlier, all of the URBN will be focusing on how to be faster speed to market, use more predictive tools and resources and, overtime, lower inventories in total for the organization. As it relates to Anthropologie and the sequential growth, we did see that in Q2. However, when we look at the balance of the year, I wanted to remember that about 6 months ago, we launched wI think Meg sort of overhaul of the Anthropologie's vision for architects, our process, speed to market, the teams have changed and that's about 6 months ago. And we expect fall and holiday to be sort of similar to Q2, where the company will look similar to Q2's results and expanded product categories will outpace apparel's growth, yet still see opportunities to show improved merchandise margins over the prior year, even with apparel being softer in the balance of the year relative to comps.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the rain Hutchison from Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from the rain Hutchison from Bank of America.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow-up on inventory. I know you just touch on some of it for Anthro. But inventory seem lean across the chain this quarter. Do the strong reaction to the initial fall items tend to at all to invest more heavily in inventory, especially
componenttext: I just wanted to follow-up on inventory. I know you just touch on some of it for Anthro. But inventory seem lean across the chain this quarter. Do the strong reaction to the initial fall items tend to at all to invest more heavily in inventory, especially as there is newness and fashion for the back half?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Lorraine, the decrease in inventory is planned. And we are planning to decrease inventory further. But we don't think that it impacts sales negatively. We actually think it will impact sales possibly because our other goal is to be able to replenish
componenttext: Okay, Lorraine, the decrease in inventory is planned. And we are planning to decrease inventory further. But we don't think that it impacts sales negatively. We actually think it will impact sales possibly because our other goal is to be able to replenish those things that are selling well faster. So to that end, Barbara and her team in sourcing have implemented a lot of initiatives that are going to allow us to speed up the time that it takes us to replenish. And as we get faster and faster, I think you'll see inventory decrease even further, but hopefully, sales will go up because we have the right product in the right place at the right time.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Simeon Siegel from Nomura Securities.

componenttext: With the top line acceleration throughout the quarter, can you just share any color on August trends? And just with UO and Anthropologie reaching near the record margins, can you just talk to where you expect those kinds of operating margins to write out this year? And maybe how you think about the ongoing opportunity to push beyond the peaks after the next couple of quarters?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think from a macro level, so URBN level, we think that t,e sales are going to be relatively consistent or are relatively consistent, obvious, today with the total Q2 results. Remember, we're on a calendar basis, so the early August comparisons are up ag
componenttext: I think from a macro level, so URBN level, we think that t,e sales are going to be relatively consistent or are relatively consistent, obvious, today with the total Q2 results. Remember, we're on a calendar basis, so the early August comparisons are up against the next weekend last year, which causes us about probably 1%, 1.5% different. So we're down slightly to the Q2 results. But overall, we think we're about even when you factor in the extra weekend.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Brian Tunick from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] on for Brian. I guess, just on gross margin, Frank, you indicated that you expect the gross margin to be up in 3Q, but maybe moderating slightly from the second quarter. Can you just talk about behind some of your assumptions withi
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] on for Brian. I guess, just on gross margin, Frank, you indicated that you expect the gross margin to be up in 3Q, but maybe moderating slightly from the second quarter. Can you just talk about behind some of your assumptions within that? And specifically, how should we think about merch margins across the brand and also delivery and fulfillment expense for the gross margin? I remember last year, that was a headwind in 3Q. Thank you very much.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Keith. This is Frank. You're correct that we do believe that we can right now deliver improved gross profit margin in the third quarter. We delivered about 142 basis points of improved gross profit margin for the first half of that year. We think Q3
componenttext: Yes, Keith. This is Frank. You're correct that we do believe that we can right now deliver improved gross profit margin in the third quarter. We delivered about 142 basis points of improved gross profit margin for the first half of that year. We think Q3 could come in around 100 basis points. There's obviously assumes that the Urban Outfitters brand continues to the strong momentum that they have right now that Anthropologie post similar performance to see what they delivered in the second quarter. And Free People delivers sequential improvement in their markdown rate in the third quarter from where they landed in the second quarter do due to inventory being in a better position. But by line item, the improved MMU would be through improved initial markups at both the Anthropologie and Urban Outfitters brand and potentially a lower markdown at all 3 of our brands for the third quarter.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016

componenttext: So I guess, I'm just curious if you could dig a little bit into the customers that's coming into for back into the stores at Urban and Anthropologie, but even what you're seeing at Free People. componenttext: Okay. I'm going to ask Chris and David and Sheila also to talk about it. She can talk about it too. So Trish?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Hi, Marni. What we're seeing is definitely still our core customer, our 18 to 28 core customer. And what we're seeing, and I mentioned that in the script, is in all buckets of customer, new and reactivated, we're seeing really nice growth both in
componenttext: Thanks. Hi, Marni. What we're seeing is definitely still our core customer, our 18 to 28 core customer. And what we're seeing, and I mentioned that in the script, is in all buckets of customer, new and reactivated, we're seeing really nice growth both in North America and Europe. So the answer to the question, really just getting that core 18 to 28-year customers back in the brand.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marni. For Anthropologie Group, we're seeing stability in the customer file and the types of people coming in. Though obviously, with product category shifts, we do see some differences, so we do hear of customers coming in who are new to the brand becaus
componenttext: Marni. For Anthropologie Group, we're seeing stability in the customer file and the types of people coming in. Though obviously, with product category shifts, we do see some differences, so we do hear of customers coming in who are new to the brand because they may be passionate about home, the beauty assortment being a little different, also watching what's happening with the primary apparel-only shoppers. we look at it. But we also know as we get into Q3 that the Anthropologie customer really stores to shop aggressively after the kids have got into school, so we'll be looking after the kids go back to school to get the [indiscernible] fall.

componenttext: I guess, my question was on the fourth quarter, with new fashion trends emerging and the green shoots that you're seeing across brands, barring the environment, could we expect both Urban and Anthro to comp positively in the fourth quarter? componenttext: I'll take the first part of it, and I don't want to be rude, but we can't speculate about comps in the fourth quarter. Trends right now would suggest it's possible, but we don't know for sure and we can't speculate.

componenttext: And this is Frank. I'll reiterate that. I mean, certainly, there is opportunity for the first [ph] [indiscernible] fourth [ph] quarter, but if our trends were to continue. But, as you know, this is retail and that just feel like it's a long way out right now.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: The next question is from Omar Saad from Evercore ISI.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering on Anthropologie. The success you guys are having in many of the nonapparel categories, and I know you're optimistic about apparel improving. But the larger-format stores,  there's a new larger-format real estate that's probably coming ope
componenttext: I was wondering on Anthropologie. The success you guys are having in many of the nonapparel categories, and I know you're optimistic about apparel improving. But the larger-format stores,  there's a new larger-format real estate that's probably coming open, maybe some mall anchor space. Have you thought about really pushing that angle for the brand, perhaps accelerating that format?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Omar, we couldn't be more pleased with the start we've had with a large format concept that we launched during the URBN 2020 vision session. And also get around the customer and her appetite for the brand and like all of the URBN brands, product category
componenttext: Omar, we couldn't be more pleased with the start we've had with a large format concept that we launched during the URBN 2020 vision session. And also get around the customer and her appetite for the brand and like all of the URBN brands, product category expansions have been a wonderful opportunity for us. The first -- it's only been 3 months, but she certainly seems to be enjoying the experience and the product offer. And we're still working through and learning how do operate and maximize that opportunity. As Dick said, we believe with what's going on in the digital environment that it's more important that our offer be -- not only will our offer be compelling but the in-store experience be compelling. And we think these are very experiential, including what the team is adding in terms of dining and all the product categories and our new services selling model. We're opening hopefully 3 more this year. We have slated loosely 4 to 5 the following year. And if these results were to continue, we hope to see what this also activates the broader assortment online, which will be there both. So we're again, very early in stages in terms of time and categories and less of upside, but like you intimated, we think this is a very healthy sign from our customer acknowledgment of the strategy.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ike Burch our from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question is from Ike Burch our from Wells Fargo.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the one category, the Anthro that was negative is women's apparel. Can you just remind us what percent of their business that represents? And then just curious, which product categories within apparel do you have the most confidence in that
componenttext: You mentioned the one category, the Anthro that was negative is women's apparel. Can you just remind us what percent of their business that represents? And then just curious, which product categories within apparel do you have the most confidence in that can show improvement in the back half and which might take a little bit longer?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's David here again. Regarding Anthropologie apparel, again, as we look at it, we see --  we're 6 months since working through this. We've seen the terrific work that Meg and the leaders have done at Free People and Urban, so we're really -- we believe
componenttext: It's David here again. Regarding Anthropologie apparel, again, as we look at it, we see --  we're 6 months since working through this. We've seen the terrific work that Meg and the leaders have done at Free People and Urban, so we're really -- we believe we're headed down the right path with a new approach. The teams are starting to work together well, it was trying to understand that architypes and potential than learning how to react. And with that confidence, the margins and planners will start to feel better about those investments. Dick alluded to we've had double-digit successes in dresses. We, too, are excited about the fashion changes and think Anthropologie's customer will adapt to fashion moods at a different way and a different pace than the other 2 brand customers. But we are seeing some really interesting movement in denim. Wovens continue to show some nice highlights, and we're seeing is a lot of interesting reads. That being said, we are expecting and anticipate it to continue to land the performance of the expanded categories for fall holiday time period, but continuing to learn each season.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: The next question is from Dana Telsey from Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you think about the changes in Anthro, do any of the success factors of Urban Outfitters, whether it's the exclusive product offering or the working with brand partners, will any of those be an opportunity for Anthro?
componenttext: As you think about the changes in Anthro, do any of the success factors of Urban Outfitters, whether it's the exclusive product offering or the working with brand partners, will any of those be an opportunity for Anthro?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Dana, I'll take the question. I think absolutely, there is learnings that can -- that are applicable. It might not be as direct as what we see happening at Urban, but I think the idea of collaborations with the different designers, different artisan
componenttext: Okay, Dana, I'll take the question. I think absolutely, there is learnings that can -- that are applicable. It might not be as direct as what we see happening at Urban, but I think the idea of collaborations with the different designers, different artisans and artists are absolutely applicable for the Anthropologie customer. And as we get into home, I think that, that gives even more opportunity. So I would expect you to see the same sort of thing at all 3 brands. I think, what Urban has done is really very powerful and the customer obviously is reacting extremely well.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016

componenttextpreview: Neely, thank you so much. I'm really glad you're looking what you're seeing. Yes, as we find partners that are like-minded and it makes sense and we know there are brands that will resonate with our customer, we'll for sure pursue those as a great partner
componenttext: Neely, thank you so much. I'm really glad you're looking what you're seeing. Yes, as we find partners that are like-minded and it makes sense and we know there are brands that will resonate with our customer, we'll for sure pursue those as a great partner. There's no specific number of or there's no specific -- it's a far more organic process. In terms of the depth, to your point, where we are seeing success, yes, we are going back and managing that inventory [indiscernible]

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we do see, Neely, is a lot of brands 'coming to was and wanting to partner because they see the credibility that has given some of our partners. So I think that, yes, we will continue to do this. We'll continue to expand that, but will be extremely s
componenttext: What we do see, Neely, is a lot of brands 'coming to was and wanting to partner because they see the credibility that has given some of our partners. So I think that, yes, we will continue to do this. We'll continue to expand that, but will be extremely selective in who we do it with.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Richard Jaffe from Stifel.
componenttext: The next question is from Richard Jaffe from Stifel.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question about Europe and the Anthropologie business. It was a slow start for Anthropologie over the season. It looks like it's really picking up pace. Wondering if it's matching the performance of Urban and? If so, is it the trajectory going to a
componenttext: A quick question about Europe and the Anthropologie business. It was a slow start for Anthropologie over the season. It looks like it's really picking up pace. Wondering if it's matching the performance of Urban and? If so, is it the trajectory going to accelerate what the outlook for Anthropologie?

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, Anthropologie Europe did have -- did see some improvements. I wouldn't say it's at the pace of what Trish and team experienced in Europe this past quarter. That being said, as we discussed on the March call, we think all of URBN has German this g
componenttext: Richard, Anthropologie Europe did have -- did see some improvements. I wouldn't say it's at the pace of what Trish and team experienced in Europe this past quarter. That being said, as we discussed on the March call, we think all of URBN has German this growth potential, Europe, Asia and beyond. We announced during that time that we were going to hire a leader. On our last, call. We announced that, that Stephan joined us and he's going to be heading up the international strategy in strategic growth and working with the brand leaders to find this opportunity, not only for Anthropologie, but others. Also, want to take a moment while I have you to follow-up on the other prong of my new role, which was URBN digital growth and wanted to let you know we're very happy to announce the promotion of Dave Hayne, who will be the news Chief Digital Officer for URBN, taking some of the experiences and great track records he has been working with Megan Sheila and team at building Free People's digital growth and working with the brands to carve out that strategy as we move ahead along with international.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I might add, Richard, all 3 brands saw strength in Europe this past quarter. Urban had very good Retail segment comp sales as it did Anthropologie, but not to forget Free People. The Free People Wholesale division almost doubled their sales in Europe,
componenttext: If I might add, Richard, all 3 brands saw strength in Europe this past quarter. Urban had very good Retail segment comp sales as it did Anthropologie, but not to forget Free People. The Free People Wholesale division almost doubled their sales in Europe, so almost counterintuitive because of all the political noise that was coming out of Europe. But Europe right now is performing very well.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from John Morris with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our last question comes from John Morris with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dick, I think if we want to continue with that thought, that was actually going to be my question in terms of what you attribute, I mean, a very impressive performance in Europe given that we've heard a lot of retailers having had a pretty challenging qua
componenttext: Dick, I think if we want to continue with that thought, that was actually going to be my question in terms of what you attribute, I mean, a very impressive performance in Europe given that we've heard a lot of retailers having had a pretty challenging quarter there. And I'm wondering what you attribute that strength and resilience to of the brand overseas as it may apply to what's to come ahead.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, John. The only thing I can attribute to is product and some theme changes at Urban. At Urban, we've brought on some new members of the team and they are performing extremely well, and we're very pleased with them. At Anthropologie, there have not be
componenttext: Okay, John. The only thing I can attribute to is product and some theme changes at Urban. At Urban, we've brought on some new members of the team and they are performing extremely well, and we're very pleased with them. At Anthropologie, there have not been a lot of changes to the team, so I can't attribute it to that. But I think, again and again, it's always about product and execution. And I think we did a much better job executing this year and the product is better. And I believe that's our last question. And I thank everybody for being on the call. And hope to talk to you next quarter. Thank you.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016

componenttext: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Urban Outfitters Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 16, 2016
